Hello, fellow history major here. Here are some thoughts worth considering:

* As soon as I saw that you were working on a teaching career, my mind immediately went to substitute teaching. In my area, subs make $95-110 a day depending on the district. That[.] $13-15 an hour, easy. $18 if you do kindergarten. I would highly recommend this since it is easy to get into, you can start working quickly, and you get experience in one of the most important parts of running a classroom: Classroom Management.

* History degrees are not worthless. In you plan on becoming a history teacher, a professional historian, or teaching college history, then a history degree is really the only choice. Don't buy into the whole STEM degrees are the only degrees that matter. Yes, an engineer will make a higher salary than many humanities degree holders. Nevertheless, a history degree will give you the skillset that is still desirable in the workplace: forming a persuasive argument; conducting solid research; writing well; and understanding human relationships etc.

https://www. forbes. com/sites/georgeanders/2015/07/29/liberal_arts-degree-tech/#8492fd6745d2

* You are correct in the sense that history knowledge itself would not be useful unless you are directly working in a history related field like I mentioned in my first point. Nevertheless, the skills you developed in pursuit of that degree make you marketable for a host of jobs that have to do with writing. Here are a few: exhibit designer; content creator; business analyst; social media manager; copywriter; editor; et al.
